item.title: One of the first tasks I will ask my new community cabinet to...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

One of the first tasks I will ask my new community cabinet to undergo will be evaluating my first year in office as a member of the Denver School Board. I believe in accountability and understand that I have a lot of growing to do as an elected official. In order for me to be better, I must hold myself accountable to my bosses and that is the community.
item.author: Tay Anderson

item.title: Anderson said Jones will serve as “an inspiration to our Black...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

Anderson said Jones will serve as “an inspiration to our Black men in Denver Public Schools that they can see themselves reflected in the highest points of leadership.”

#edcolo

Jones will start his new role Jan. 1 as the school board searches for a permanent leader.

co.chalkbeat.org

Dwight Jones named interim superintendent of Denver Public Schools

item.title: I’m grateful the Mayor has come around to support decisions by...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

I’m grateful the Mayor has come around to support decisions by the Denver School Board.

Michael B. Hancock

I’m pleased to support the selection of Dwight Jones as interim Superintendent of Denver Public Schools. DPS needs a leader right now who understands and has st...rong relationships with the community and other stakeholders, and I believe Jones will be able to provide that leadership during this transition period.

You can read my full statement here: https://www.denvergov.org/…/mayor-hancock-statement-on-sele…

item.title: ** DISCLAIMER I AM RESTING ** I am re-opening the application to...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

** DISCLAIMER I AM RESTING **

I am re-opening the application to join my 'Community Cabinet' for the next 24 hours. I am building a team of individuals that want to support building a better future for Denver Public Schools.

APPLY HERE: https://forms.gle/xBiNgbp7p2Pqpbwd7

Director Anderson wants to build a strong coalition of students, educators, and community members to advise policy and uplift all voices in Denver Public Schools. This Community Cabinet will meet on the SECOND SATURDAY each month from 10:00 AM - 11:30 AM via ZOOM.

Today Director Anderson suffered severe chest pains and collapsed at Target.

He is in stable condition and will be receiving further testing.

We want to thank the staff at Target and the EMT’s for their help to ensure he was taken care of.

item.title: When I think about people I am grateful for, I think of this...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

When I think about people I am grateful for, I think of this amazing team of elected officials working for our students, educators, and communities in Denver Public Schools.

We may not always agree on everything, but we have a dedication to ensuring that our district thrives.

item.title: Today I am reflecting on what I am thankful for. Today I will...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

Today I am reflecting on what I am thankful for.

Today I will not celebrate white settlers coming over to occupy & steal Indigenous land.

Today and everyday should be a reminder that nobody is illegal on stolen land.

item.title: This is what happens when the Mayor, Former Mayor Pena, and...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

This is what happens when the Mayor, Former Mayor Pena, and Former DPS School Board Directors put out false statements to our city regarding the resignation of Superintendent Cordova.

Now I am calling on all of them to issue a statement condemning this behavior.

item.author: Tay Anderson

item.title: Folks have emailed, called, texted, etc. on why I have been so...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

Folks have emailed, called, texted, etc. on why I have been so critical of the Mayor and Fmr. School Board Directors.

Today on the Brother Jeff Network some of the Fmr. SB Directors were on the show and when asked to provide evidence to support their claims they could not. When they called this board hostile, dysfunctional, discriminatory, etc. with no evidence and refused to talk with us before making public statements with false allegations they were aware of the negative ...implications that it would have in our communities.

Now I can not speak for the outgoing Superintendent, but when she announced this decision to our families she said she was NOT looking for a new job and that this had been a reoccurring ask from the Dallas ISD Superintendent. She has been very outspoken and honest and did not mention any push out from members of this School Board. So right now what is best for out students and teachers is that we get back to work for them.

I welcome anyone that has made a public statement condemning this board to also put resources, money, and personal time to helping us ensure that we can re-open our schools if COVID cases trend down over the remainder of 2020. I am always open to working together for our students, but I will not tolerate lies, undermining, or attempts to divide our communities to score political points.

See More
item.author: Tay Anderson

item.title: Colorado Latino Forum speaks out in response to the departure of...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

Colorado Latino Forum speaks out in response to the departure of Superintendent Cordova.

Colorado Latino Forum

CLF dispels the myths that there is a monolithic Latino or Latina group that speaks for the interests of all Latinos in the City of Denver and specifically with... respect to the superintendent drama at Denver Public Schools (DPS). Current DPS Superintendent Susanna Cordova resigned last week of her own accord. She announced that she was recruited and accepted a high-level position at a school district in the Dallas, Texas area. Furthermore, she will take a hefty pension from the DPS budget that will allow her to effectively “double-dip” and live quite comfortably. She departs as many school district leaders across Colorado and the nation jump ship during the middle of the COVID-19 pandemic as students languish without adequate access to the internet for remote learning from home as their parents struggle to make ends meet and the added challenge to secure childcare.

Mayor Hancock has decried Cordova’s resignation and has begun a coordinated and far-fetched effort to rebrand a simple resignation as “racism” and “sexism.” This smacks of the familiar political opportunism that Mayor Hancock, and ERN/DFER cronies have heaped on all of Denver’s Latino community for far too long. The outgoing superintendent upheld her corporate interests and her family profited from her efforts in more ways than one. The “reform” crowd who is screaming “racism” is actually hurting the movement for racial, social and education justice. CLF reminds Denver that under the outgoing superintendent actually threatened striking teachers, most of them Latinas, with deportation. Furthermore, this same superintendent who hails from Denver, effectively drove her own alma mater at Lincoln High School into state intervention from the Colorado Department of Education after dividing the school into pieces for the benefit of corporate charter schools. These misappropriations, lies and racist actions by the Cordova-led administration cannot allow us to mischaracterize her lucrative departure as her being a victim to racism.

The sitting elected seven-member Board of Education members must engage in a search for a nationally-acclaimed superintendent of the highest caliber that supports —not a back-door, handpicked crony from a current meddling, opportunistic mayor. Denver deserves top-notch candidates who can steer the billion-dollar plus behemoth that is the independent government of DPS on a course that takes our students to their highest educational and social potential. Let’s stop calling racism when millionaires don’t get their way and support the Denver School Board’s search for an equity-driven, pro-public education candidate for this critical position.

#DPS #superintendent
Please see attached image for full statement.

See More
item.author: Tay Anderson

item.title: Statement from our President and Vice President:
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

Statement from our President and Vice President:

Denver School Board President, Dr. Carrie A. Olson

Vice President Jennifer Bacon and I just recorded this statement regarding the impending superintendent search on behalf of all of the Board of Education of Den...ver Public Schools. I'll post the recording here when I have it. THANK YOU to all of you who are offering support and help during these challenging times. During these times of crisis, we remember what Mr. Rogers says, “Look for the helpers. You will always find people who are helping.” We see you and we appreciate you.

“Thank you to everyone for your continued support and feedback as we navigate yet another difficult transition for Denver Public Schools. We are sending this statement to speak to Denverites who are made up of our students, our staff, our neighbors, and our community members. We speak to you as duly elected members, selected by you, to represent your voice on the Denver Public Schools Board of Education. We are former teachers in DPS, we are organizers, we are parents of DPS students, we are bilingual. We are a recent alum, a reverend, a lawyer, a child of immigrants, and a former lieutenant governor. We are honored to lead the students of DPS into a future where all students can receive the best public education to thrive and learn. Students are always at the forefront of all we do.

We are grateful for the many comments, suggestions and voices that have provided us with a lot of feedback and much to consider. We welcome the chance to talk with everyone including fellow elected leaders, once we have a process in place. We also want and encourage the many voices in our community, who care so deeply about our schools, to help us during this process. We always receive feedback from the communities we represent with openness and reflection. Our goal has remained steadfast; ensuring we have the best schools for the students in our community.

We have been working through the timeline for transition, naming an interim, and a process for a superintendent search. We ask for your patience keeping in mind we are in the midst of a pandemic. We will share the process with the community before any decisions are made. We will also announce an interim leader during the first week of December.

The Board has been clear that the Superintendent and her staff focus on the crisis priorities over the last 6 months in order to best serve our students and staff during this pandemic. In addition, the superintendent and the Board agreed to delay work on the next Denver Plan to best meet the urgent needs of our families in DPS. And, we know that this board believes in community voice as evidenced by the work we’ve taken on and how we’ve elevated students, teachers and principals voices. In addition we’ve highlighted the voices of the communities who elected us. We are committed to listening to all voices in our search, so that our students can have the public schools that they deserve..

All Board members were surprised and saddened by Susana Cordova’s departure. We wish her the best of luck in her new job in Dallas. Any superintendent taking over when she did would have stepped into a difficult position. When she started DPS was in transition as we came off of 10 years of one administration. That meant there were challenging situations to manage, with new points of view. When we hired her, we recognized that she had the skills and passion to work with DPS. As we face leadership changes, one thing that stay the same is our commitment to prioritizing our students,

How we spend our time over the next days and months will be critical. Any time we spend discussing external claims takes us away from our priorities focused on placing an interim superintendent to guide us through this transition; and reopening our schools for our students and teachers.

Like we always say to our students, be kind to each other. We are community and we will need each other. We call on everyone to model for our students how we can work together to build a strong public education system that we can all be proud of. We too always welcome constructive help and feedback. We particularly welcome help from any city leader, former school board member, and any concerned community leader to reopen our schools for a safe return in January.

Again, we look forward to finding the next great leader of DPS. We will continue to work towards our vision of grassroots decision making, and elevating the voices of our most precious stakeholders. We commit to seeing this moment as an opportunity to reflect on the past but not repeat it, and embrace the possibilities for all of our students. We will be providing updates to the community as we work to find a new leader for DPS."

See More
item.author: Tay Anderson

item.title: *** Social Media Policy *** Guidelines for functioning in an...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

*** Social Media Policy ***

Guidelines for functioning in an electronic world are the same as the values, ethics and respectability policies expected to live every day. You can expect discussions on many topics and many viewpoints in my posts. You can also expect the following:

*Engagement in healthy, open and honest dialogues

...

*Welcoming of constructive criticism

*Corrections of inaccurate or misleading postings

*Deletion of posts that are spam, inappropriate, defamatory, use profanity, and/or otherwise offensive

*An understanding that respect goes both ways — I will use good judgment in my posts and respond to you in a respectful manner. In return, I ask the same of you. (If instances of bullying and/or harassment take place, I may unfriend, block and or report the matter to Facebook, depending on the seriousness of the situation.)

*Honoring of our differences — I will not tolerate discrimination (including age, sex, race, color, creed, religion, ethnicity, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, citizenship, disability, or marital status or any other legally recognized protected basis under federal, state, or local laws, regulations or ordinances).

For further questions on this policy please email me at Tay_Anderson@dpsk12.org

See More
item.author: Tay Anderson
